I'll say this - not all steaks should be cooked the same way. Depending on the type of the steak (ex. ribeye, strip, filet), different temperatures are considered ideal. Some are actually best served medium-well (NY Strip, imho), while others should be medium-rare or rare.
So all told... I can't blame a chef who'd select a lesser quality cut for a diner that has clearly asked for temperature that doesn't properly match the type. For example, if you ask for a filet cooked medium-well - I'm giving you crappiest filet in my kitchen.

Disclaimer: I am not a chef and do not work in a restaurant.

The physical properties of each steak is too different, I don’t think the grill is very scientific because how you treat each steak could make a big difference in the result.
Sous Vide is the only way to equally cook steaks that are this different from each other; after sous vide they could be cubed to equal sizes (not literal cubes, just the largest piece that can be cut from all the samples) before briefly applying the flame or pan-sear finish.
Plus, that way it would be easier to adjust the number of steaks you start with so you get the same number of strips by the time you plate them.
